intro: Galium subvelutinum, commonly known as hairy bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender stems and small, opposite leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white to pale pink flowers during the summer months. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Galium subvelutinum is often found in association with other woodland plants and is adapted to temperate climates.
